title-group.subtitle: Applying Quantile Regression to the National Football League Market for Linebackers

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Quinn Andrew Wesley Keefer is a PhD student in economics at Claremont Graduate University. His research interests include behavioral economics, industrial organization and sports economics.

abstract.p: Using data from 2001 to 2009, quantile regression techniques are used to analyze the presence of discrimination in the National Football League (NFL) market for linebackers. This article uses both binary variable and decomposition approaches. An extension of the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition to quantile regression, proposed by Melly, is estimated to decompose the earnings gap across the distribution. This article concludes that discrimination is present in the linebacker market. This result is robust to approach and evident across the entire distribution. This result differs from much of the previous research on professional football.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There have been many studies examining the effects of race on compensation in professional sports. Research has studied nearly all professional sports labor markets including professional football. However, the National Football League (NFL) has been studied less than other sports such as baseball and basketball. Rosen and Sanderson (2001) state in their comprehensive review of professional sports labor markets that compensation discrimination was evident in U.S. professional sports in the 1960s and 1970s. However, in more recent time periods, there has been little to no evidence of discrimination. This evidence is supported by Kahn (2009) in his discussion of discrimination in professional basketball. His survey of the literature displays a shift from robust compensation discrimination against Black players in the 1980s (Brown, Spiro & Keenan, 1991; Kahn & Sherer, 1988; Koch & Vander Hill, 1988; Wallace, 1988) to no evidence of salary discrimination in the 1990s through 2002 (Bodvarsson & Brastow, 1998; Dey, 1997; Eschker, Perez, & Siegler, 2004; Gius & Johnson, 1998; Hamilton, 1997; Kahn & Shah, 2005).

Several prominent papers have, similarly, concluded that there is very little to no compensation discrimination in the NFL. Kahn (1991, 1992) and Mogull (1973, 1981) found that there is essentially no discrimination in the NFL. Kahn (1992) found there to be approximately a 4% difference in compensation between Black and non-Black players. However, in alternative specifications, this number is closer to 1% and not significant.

However, more recent research has come to different conclusions. Gius and Johnson (2000) found reverse discrimination with Black players earning more than Whites by 10%. However, their analysis uses a sample of players from multiple positions in the NFL. As Leeds and Kowalewski (2001) have noted, players in the NFL are valued on a position-specific basis. Therefore, controlling for individual performance is empirically difficult when analyzing multiple positions.

A recent article by Berri and Simmons (2009) found a possible discrimination against Black quarterbacks. They find that rushing yards is not a rewarded measure of performance for quarterbacks in the NFL. They conclude that since Black quarterbacks utilize rushing as a larger portion of their skill set this may represent compensation discrimination.

This article’s analysis addresses the lack of research for defensive players in the NFL. Thus far, position-specific studies of compensation in the NFL have focused on offensive skilled positions (Berri & Simmons, 2009; Leeds & Kowalewski, 2001).1 The previous research of defensive and non-skilled positions has been included in surveys of the entire NFL.2 This article extends the research of compensation discrimination in the NFL to defensive and non-skilled positions.

Of the three major defensive positions, defensive line, linebacker, and defensive back, linebackers represent a unique opportunity for compensation analysis. Compared to the other positions, linebackers represent a relatively racially diverse group. Also, the number of relevant performance measures exceeds that of either defensive lineman or defensive backs. Linebackers are not only important in both rush and pass defense but also in pass coverage and quarterback pressure. This is unique from defensive lineman, who are important in rush defense and quarterback pressure, and defensive backs, who are primarily for pass coverage.

sec.title: Model
sec.p:
This analysis uses the standard earnings function log-linear estimation. Let Yi,t denote the natural logarithm of player i’s salary for year t and xi,t denote the vector of independent variables.Yi,t=α+βxi,t+εi,t
Equation 1: Standard ordinary least squares (OLS) Earnings Function.
Earnings functions have traditionally been estimated using the OLS approach, which estimates the parameters at the conditional mean. This is the most efficient estimator under the assumption of normal error distribution, but is very sensitive to outlier values. However, the quantile regression approach of Koenker and Bassett (1978) is robust to the presence of outliers and non-normal distributions. Quantile regression also allows for the effect of independent variables to vary across the distribution. It assumes the conditional θth quantile of the dependent variable is a linear combination of the independent variables. Thus, it estimates the conditional θth quantile, rather than the mean like OLS, given the vector of independent variables.3 Yi,t=α(θ)+β(θ)xi,t+ϵθi,tQθ[Yi,t |xi,t]=α(θ)+β(θ)×xi,t.
Equation 2: Quantile Regression Earnings Function. Where, QθYi,t|xi,t is the quantile function conditional on the independent variables. Intercept and coefficient values are functions of the quantile.
This is informative in the estimation of earnings functions, as the marginal effect of independent variables almost certainly varies across the distribution. For this reason, quantile regressions are frequently estimated in labor economics. Sports labor markets are no exception to the use of quantile regression (Leeds & Kowalewski, 2001; Vincent & Eastman, 2009).

To measure the presence of discrimination in the labor market, two approaches are taken. The first is the standard and simple dummy variable approach. A binary variable for race is included in the estimation. From the results, conclusions are made about the significance of race as a determinant of compensation.

However, this simple approach does not directly allow for conclusions to be made about discrimination in the labor market. Oaxaca (1973) and Blinder (1973) developed a method for analyzing discrimination in the labor market. The Oaxaca Blinder decomposition is a method for decomposing a wage gap into explained and unexplained portions. The explained portion is due to a difference in endowments or the average characteristics of the groups. The unexplained portion is due to differences in the returns to the independent variables; this portion is the measure of discrimination. Let the superscript H denote the group earning higher wages and L denote the group earning lower wages.Yi,tH=αH+βH×xi,tH+εi,tH,Yi,tL=αL+βL×xi,tL+εi,tL,Y¯H=αH+βH×x¯H,Y¯L=αL+βL×x¯L,Y¯H−Y¯L=βH×(x¯H−x¯L)+x¯L×(βH−βL)+αH−αL.
Equation 3: Oaxaca Blinder Decomposition. Where x¯L×(βH−βL)+αH−αL is the measure of discrimination.
The Oaxaca Blinder decomposition relies on OLS estimates at the conditional mean. However, the desired estimation method is quantile regression. This analysis uses the method derived by Melly (2006) and further detailed in Chernozhukov, Fernández-Val, and Melly (2009) for extending the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition to the entire distribution of earnings rather than just the conditional mean. The method is referred to as quantile treatment effects (QTE). The QTE is synonymous to the wage gap in the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition. However, QTE is measuring the difference between the quantiles of the groups and not the means. The QTE is decomposed similar to the Oaxaca Blinder method into endowment and coefficient effects called quantile treatment effects on the treated (QTET). The QTET measures discrimination at different points of the earnings distribution by constructing the counterfactual distribution. This estimation technique is shown to be identical to the Machado and Mata (2005) estimator when infinite simulations are performed.4 Let N be a binary variable for race taking the value 1 for non-Black and the value 0 for Black.FY(1)−1(θ)−FY(0)−1(θ) QTEFY(1)−1(θ|N=1)−FY(0)−1(θ|N=1)QTET.
Equation 4: Quantile Treatment Effects (QTE). Where FY(N)−1(θ) is the θth quantile function of Y for group N.
The Melly (2006) QTE estimator allows for hypothesis testing and inference by bootstrapping.5

sec.title: Specification
sec.p: NFL players' contracts are generally multiple year contracts that specify three distinct sources of compensation. The three components of an NFL salary are a base salary, incentive bonuses, and signing bonus. The base salary is a specified amount for each year of the contract. Incentive bonuses are specified and rewarded for a vast number of things. Many incentive bonuses are performance-based bonuses paid to a player for reaching a specified level in a certain statistical category. Another example of an incentive bonus is training. Teams may give players bonuses for training with members of the organization in the off-season rather than training on their own. The final part of an NFL contract is the signing bonus. The NFL is distinct from other sports leagues in that NFL contracts are not guaranteed (Staudohar, 1998). The base salary and incentive bonuses stipulated in a contract may not be paid to the player if he is released by the organization. However, the signing bonus is guaranteed as it is a bonus paid at the origination of the contract. The NFL, unlike Major League Baseball or the National Hockey League, has a salary cap making the signing bonus even more important. Teams are allowed to amortize the signing bonus for the length of the contract. Therefore, the most appropriate measure of a player’s compensation is his salary cap value, the sum of his base salary, incentive bonuses, and amortized value of his signing bonus.

Contracts are negotiated prior to the start of the season. Players receive their salary biweekly only during the 16 game, NFL regular season. This equates to nine paydays per year for an NFL player (Cummings, 2008). Therefore, salary must be correlated to previous performance. This effectively eliminates rookies and any players who did not play the prior year. These players, primarily rookies, are paid based on other indicators, such as college production.

The explanatory variables include vectors of individual characteristics, performance measures, and salary inflation controls. The vector of individual characteristics includes race, experience, position, and draft variables. Race is controlled for using a binary variable non-black. The linebacker position can be further specified as inside and outside linebackers. Here inside linebackers played in the middle position of a 4–3 defense or one of the two interior positions of a 3–4 defense (See Appendix). Therefore, a binary variable, ilb, is included to control for position. Players' experience is included in its level and squared form to control for decreasing marginal returns to experience. Finally, the position players were selected in and the draft is controlled using a series of draft round binary variables.

The performance vector is broken into individual and team performance measures. Due to the fact that salary cap value is dependent on previous year performance, both individual and team performance variables are lagged 1 year. Individual performance is measured by numerous statistics recorded by the NFL. The process of recording these statistics is important. The measure tackles is included as solo tackles. During the course of a football game, there are many times a ball carrier is tackled by multiple defenders. In this case, each defender is awarded an assist. When a ball carrier is tackled primarily by a single defender he is awarded a solo tackle. Here solo tackles are used to prevent double counting tackles for multiple players. The same logic may seem applicable to sacks. However, sacks are recorded differently. If a single player makes a sack, he is awarded a single sack in the statistics. However, if two players combine for a sack, they are each given a half sack. Therefore, double counting is not an issue with sacks. The NFL version of an all-star game is the Pro Bowl. Players are selected to the Pro Bowl by their peers. Therefore, a binary variable, pro bowl, is included to control for peer valuation.

There in an inherent problem with continuous measures of performance in this context. Increased production, for example tackles, may be a sign of poor defensive performance. The more opportunities a player has, the more tackles etc. he will accumulate. To control for this effect, team performance variables are included. The amount of points allowed per game by the player’s defense and the number of yards allowed per game are included. Therefore, taking the example of tackles, the interpretation of tackles in the model is the effect of increasing the number of solo tackles holding the number of points and yards allowed per game constant. This eliminates the problem of increased production being correlated to increased opportunity from poor defensive performance. Also, to control for the effect of overall team success, the number of wins and a binary variable playoffs, indicating if the team made the playoffs, are included. Finally, to control for salary inflation, a series of year binary variables are estimated.ln⁡(SalaryCapValue)i,t=α(θ)+β(θ)×Ci,t+χ(θ)×Pi,t+φ(θ)×Ti,t+γ(θ)×Ii,t+εθ,i,t.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: This study uses data from 2001 to 2009. In 2001, the NFL began recording tackles as an official statistic. Since this is an important measure of defensive performance, the data used begin in 2001. The data set in this analysis uses all linebackers, recognized by the NFL, who played in these years. Each year represents all linebackers in the NFL for that year.

The empirical models use the most recent salary data, individual player characteristics, individual performance measures, and team performance measures. Salary data were collected from the USA Today (2009). They maintain an online database of player salaries for all major sports. The USA Today breaks NFL player salaries into five major categories: base salary, signing bonus, other bonuses, total salary, and salary cap value. Other bonuses are the player incentives discussed earlier. This study uses the natural logarithm of players' salary cap value as reported by the USA Today. The mean and quantile values of this measure are reported in Table 2.

caption.p: Mean and Quantile Values—ln (salary cap value).

sec.p: Individual player characteristics and individual and team performance measures were collected from the National Football League (2009), ESPN (2009) and Pro Football Reference (2009) online databases. All individual characteristics were collected through the NFL except position and draft selection. The position data were collected through referencing the NFL and ESPN. Several players were distinguished as either inside or outside linebackers by the NFL. For those who were not distinguished, the information was collected by viewing team depth charts. Team depth charts are available through both the NFL and ESPN. The information on draft selection number and round was collected from Pro Football Reference.

All performance data available through the NFL were collected from that source. However, NFL data were incomplete for fumble recoveries. Therefore, fumble recovery data were collected from Pro Football Reference. Data on pro bowl selections were also collected through Pro Football Reference. The means of all independent variables are reported in Table 3 .

sec.title: Dummy Variable
sec.p: The first approach taken by this analysis is the utilization of the binary variable, non-black. The sign and significance of non-black are used as an indicator of discrimination. For purposes of comparison, results for both OLS and quantile regressions are reported in Table 4 . The quantile regressions are for the 0.10, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, and 0.90 quantiles.

Utilizing an OLS approach, non-black is positive and significant at the 1% level. The coefficient value of .095 is transformed into a percentage change using Equation 6.βnon−black=∂ln(SalaryCapValue)∂non−black=ln(SalaryCapValuenon−black)−ln (SalaryCapValueblack)1.4pcβblack=lnSalaryCapValuenon−blackSalaryCapValueblackeβblack−1=SalaryCapValuenon−black−SalaryCapValueblackSalaryCapValueblackeβblack−1=% differencenon−black.
Equation 6: Conversion of Coefficient into Percentage Change.
The OLS result is that a non-Black player makes on average 10% more than a Black player, ceteris paribus. From this result, it may be concluded that discrimination is significant in the market for linebackers in the NFL.

However, the quantile regressions give much more insight into the effect of race on compensation across the distribution of ln (salary cap value). It is evident that race is a significant determinant of compensation on the lower end of the distribution. Non-black is positive and significant for the 0.10 and 0.25 quantiles. The 0.10 quantile displays an effect of 10.7% in favor of non-Black players. The 0.25 quantile has discrimination of 11.4%, again, in favor of non-Black players. From these results, it may be concluded that discrimination is present in the NFL linebacker market, but only at the lower quantiles of the distribution of ln (salary cap value). However, as discussed earlier, this is a limited approach to understanding discrimination.

sec.title: Decomposition
sec.p: To better investigate the issue of discrimination, the previously discussed decomposition methods are used. Both Oaxaca Blinder decomposition and QTE decomposition results are reported in Table 5 from the non-Black perspective. In both cases, stratified regressions are estimated for each group, non-Black and Black, OLS regressions for the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition and quantile regressions for QTE (See Appendix).

sec.p: In both cases, the portion of the differential that represents discrimination is the coefficients. From the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition, the coefficients are significant at the 1% level. Non-Black players are paid a premium of 9.4%. From this it may be concluded that discrimination is present. Utilizing the QTE, discrimination can be evaluated at different points of the distribution of ln (salary cap value). The coefficients are positive and significant, at least to the 10% level, in all five estimated quantiles. For all five estimated quantiles, discrimination against Black players is evident. Interestingly, the magnitude of discrimination is largest at the 0.10 and 0.90 quantiles. The 0.10 quantile is significant at the 1% level displaying discrimination of 10.1%. The 0.90 quantile is significant at the 5% level with 8.9% discrimination. The intermediate quantiles, 0.25, 0.50, and .075, also exhibit significant discrimination, 7.3%, 6.8%, and 8.1%, respectively.
By estimating 99 quantiles, from 0.01 through 0.99, and using the QTE decomposition, the effects can be displayed over the entire distribution (Figure 1 ).

Throughout the distribution of ln (salary cap value), there is discrimination against Black players. At very low quantiles, discrimination is very large. Discrimination sharply declines in the quantile and remains relatively constant for the rest of the distribution. From these results, it is concluded that discrimination is present in the NFL market for linebackers throughout the distribution of compensation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Examining the time period from when the NFL began officially recording tackle statistics to the present, 2001-2009, race has been shown to be important in determining linebackers' salaries. Examining this time period using several different techniques displays discrimination against Black linebackers. Each method returns similar results that discrimination is significant.

Utilizing the dummy variable approach, both OLS and quantile regressions display discrimination against Black linebackers. However, this effect is only significant at the lower end of the distribution of ln (salary cap value), the 0.10 and 0.25 quantiles. These results are then expanded upon to examine the true presence of discrimination using decomposition methods. Both the Oaxaca Blinder decomposition and the QTE decomposition are performed. Again, both results display discrimination against Black linebackers. However, unlike the dummy variable approach, this result is significant across all estimated quantiles, 0.10, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, and 0.90.

These results make it apparent that significant discrimination against Black players is evident in the NFL linebacker market. The presence of discrimination becomes even more robust across the distribution when utilizing QTE. Further research utilizing quantile regression and focusing on the decomposition method should be conducted on other positions. It should be determined if this result is an NFL wide issue or linebacker market specific.
